content:
2014
												Now that the sequel has been announced I figured I'd write a review for what is perhaps my most favorite game of the past few years.Killing Floor is a brilliant FPS survival horror, and perhaps the best (At least in my opinion) wave-based game out there. The game has a balance of gritty and serious environments and witty and morbid humor. The idea that you are working your way through a horde of genetically engineered monsters to finally go toe-to-toe with the final boss gives you that sense of achievement. And going toe-to-toe with the final boss is an achievement in itself; with traits from all other specimen combined and then some, you'll need a lot of bullets.A key aspect of Killing Floor is co-op. with seven different perks to play as that fill different roles in a team, you're gonna have a hard time doing it alone. Synergy with other players is key; you could just as easily doom another player as opposed to helping them. There is a lot more to the game than it seems at first glance. All of the specimen have different nuances and behavioral quirks that you will need to learn to survive. Fortunately the Beginner mode is very forgiving so you have plenty of opportunity to get some practice in. However, the difficulty curve is like a brick wall; it's not uncommon for even veteran players to fall to the horde on even the lower difficulties.The game is very community-driven. There are a lot of custom content for the game which is fully supported, and even some of the DLC and updates are filled with community-created content. You can expect new maps, weapons, enemies, characters, game modes and mutators.Despite being an old game it still looks beautiful and has an incredible soundtrack. There is plenty of content for this game and the only people I wouldn't suggest this game to are the squeamish.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 13
Product received for free
												Killing Floor is one of the most fun and addicting games I have ever played. The variety of maps, weapons, perks, enemies, and difficulties is immense and provides incredible depth. The characters and their dialogue are hilarious and memorable. I think this game is superior to its sequel in many ways. The gameplay is deeper and more skillful. Fast, accurate aiming and knowledge of combos is essential to becoming skilled at your chosen perk at the higher levels, and attaining these skills is rewarding and fun. You can really feel the improvement as you play more and more. KF2 by contrast lacks the same type of combos and fast, precise aim and replaces it with mad m1 spam at faster-moving hordes of zeds. The game does have its flaws in that its hitboxes are unintuitive and often misaligned with the zed models, but once you learn how the models and hitboxes work this becomes less of an obvious issue. The game also has gritty, outdated graphics, but it doesn't really look all that bad and adds to the charm of the game.Unfortunately there isn't much of a playerbase these days, but there's a lot of content to be enjoyed even for a solo player. Overall, this game is a masterpiece and you can easily spend thousands upon thousands of hours on it. Even though KF2 exists, buy KF1 and put some time into it. You won't regret it.

content:
y 20, 2014
												What is Killing Floor, you ask? British People vs Zombies: The game. Complete with Dosh, Heavy Metal, more stereotypical Brits than a Monty Python sketch, and over 32 of some of the beefiest, most satisfying Zed-killing weapons you'll encounter in a video game. There's even 'Loadsamoney' himself, Mr Harry Einfeld, present and accounted for to wreck the Zed menace. This is a game where you need to play on a difficulty higher than 'beginner' to experience. The fun of this game comes from it's challenge, and while I can understand people liking their games as easy, simple fun, the real 'survival horror' elements of this game come out when you're up against tougher enemies. I personally don't find this game scary due to the undertone silliness from all the characters models and event Zeds, but I still have a lot of fun with this game.Despite coming out back in 2009, Tripwire Interactive have been supporting this game for the last 4 years, and with each update, event and DLC pack they've added, the game's got better and better! So go ahead and pick up a copy of this now! Hell, get the 'bundle' copy which contains 90% of the game's DLC for only slightly more (trust me, most of it may be character models, but by god are they worth it).If you ever wanted a video game equivalent of Shaun of the Dead, you need to play this.

												In killing floor you fight limited waves of zombies to earn money and experience, and after each wave must visit the trader to refuel for the next wave.This game is a little difficult to start with (coming from a L4D's background), but as you and your character gain experience at it, it will become easier. there's lots of weapons to choose from and categories of proficiencies to level up in different ways.the default maps are very well done and most of them very big and detailed (but you dont have to use the whole map, you can stay in one place if that works for you).LOTS of fun in co-op, and glad it supports six players in co-op instead of just 4 (yey!) !!SO GLAD it supports local LAN play!!!!!!!!!! and you can configure map order, game style, etc easily.i dont like the in-game bullet time much and wish you could turn it off (although, it is a tiny bit helpful when you are impossibly surrounded, but that is not often enough to like it). it dirupts the flow of the game for all players.there are a few small bugs in the game that are minorly annoying and end up being the death of me sometimes, but I wont go into those.For the most part this game grew on me and I like it a LOT for now. As I level up, I increase the game difficulty to keep it challenging.

content:
14, 2014
												This game is so much fun! I got it like two weeks ago but already spent about 53 hours on it.It is a fast-paced zombie and monster shooter which can be played both in single and in multiplayer mode. It is advisable to play with others, unless you pick "easy". Already on the "normal" difficulty mode, it gets pretty tough, especially when you are on a map with lots of small paths and rooms.I like the map diversity which had been created with lots of love for details. They create just the right atmosphere, making it more realistic. The game also allows creating own maps which the modding community enjoys doing, making it even more exciting.Some of the monsters don’t really make sense but given the insanity of the Horzine boss, it isn’t that surprising. I could discuss this aspect longer but I don’t want to spoil your ideas about them.This game is exactly like I hoped the original Resident Evil Mercenary Mode to be: fast zombie hordes and lots of super monsters chasing and swarming you all over!The trader aspect is very useful, and, if we are honest, it is even realistic: people making money from those in misery. Though I wonder how the trader gets around during the zombie attacks. But, of course, you shouldn’t think about how things would work in real life. I surely wouldn’t survive such a mess, if it were real.It is very cool that you can enhance your player’s abilities over the course of time. This gives you the opportunity to try out other abilities with various advantages.The many achievements make sure you stay motivated to play it over and over – clever trick but this game definitely deserves being played often. It is very therapeutic for me, as I do something like customer support (every monster = a customer! :D)I could go on and on but I bet the other reviews already covered everything. This is supposed to present the viewpoint of a new player. :)

content:
2015
												This game... I've put almost 2000 hours into playing this game so you'd imagine that I would love this game. To be honest, I don't. I appreciate this game for what it is but it's boring and repetitive. There are maps where you can have fun camping and there are maps where you can have fun kiting but all in all, it's boring and repetitive (as with a lot of other games too).I used the word "fun" there... I use that word not to describe the game itself but the describe the experience you have with other players. It's the community that makes this game fun. The majority of the people on my friends list are people I have met through Killing Floor. There are a few who I have never spoken to outside of the game, there are a few that I speak to on a daily basis and there are a few who I have actually met in person.Would I recommend this game? Probably not. I would recommend the community. It's the people you meet, even if it's just for one game, that make this game an awesome experience!

												Probably the funnest game that involves killing hordes of undead~The game has a neat perk system so you can choose a particular class and work your levels up, this makes allies being much more important with each individual role. Map design is amazing too.8/10 for it's purpose.

er 27, 2013
												Pure carnage happens on this game. Teamwork and skill is a must to survive, as the enemies in this are no joke. A lot of weapons are available for you to engage in the massacre, in conjunction with a very well done perk system. The amount of awesome maps to play increase the game's replayability. Slow-motion specimen kills are cool to watch too. It's very exciting to be at the last wave with friends and feel hopeless as your teamates start to die and your ammo to run out, then beating the Patriarch by a close shave, feels beyond rewarding and satisfying. The graphics, while dated, are appealing. The downside is that new players might be pushed away because of the game's difficulty, since it takes a little of time to level up and get used to, even on the normal difficulty. The PVP servers are also very engaging and enjoyable to play with friends with/against each other, not to mention that it's a refreshing departure from the original survival mode. It's a blast to play, get it and enjoy it with your buddies. 8.4/10.0

content:
5, 2013
												Killing Floor is an online horde-style cooperative first person shooter that places you and other players in a map and forces you to fight waves of enemies. Your objective is simple; survive. Between each wave, a shop will open up somewhere on the map and an arrow will guide your path to find it. The trader has several weapons you can purchase and you can restore your armor and ammunition for a price.The game calls itself cooperative survival horror and while the objective in every game is survival, this is straight up in your face action horror. The monsters just come at you. There are still times where you can turn around to find half a dozen monsters trailing you. It keeps piling on the mutants and raises the intensity wave after wave.The game plays smooth, the controls are what you’d expect from a first person shooter using a mouse and keyboard. There are buttons for firing, iron sights, alternate firing, jumping, crouching, throwing grenades, reloading, running and changing your weapon. While the game lets you chose controller input, there are no native controls for it. You need to set everything yourself.While the game excels in being just a horde-style game with waves of enemies, it is just that. The maps might be different, but you will run through the same enemies depending what wave you get to. The game is devoid of objectives outside of your own survival. The maps are large, so they do offer a variety of spaces, but you can fight in the same area of a map over and over again, even if the shops opening across the map encourage you to find a different place to do battle.For anyone that chose to play offline, Killing Floor does offer a single player experience where you select a difficulty and face your foes alone. Your inventory consists of primary weapons, secondary pistols, melee weapons, a med kit and a welding torch. The torch is to seal doors shut to make it tough for enemies to get in. It also might keep you from getting out if a room fills with enemies, but leaving one door open and guarding it is a good enough tactic. Enemies will still drop in from the ceiling or jump off rooftops. You have health and body armor, both deplete when taking damage, but your health can be restored with some self stimulus while the armor needs to be purchased in from the trader.To reward you your play style there are perks that you can select between waves or games. These seven perks work like classes to benefit certain styles. Each perk starts you off with a different set of weapons. These benefits are things like faster welding speed, more damage, more health, discounts on combat armor and so on.The support specialist is good with shotguns. The sharpshooter is geared for crossbows and sniper rifles.The commando uses assault rifles and grenades. The field medic will heal others. Berserkers prefer melee weapons. Demolitions make things go boom with big weapons and firebugs make fires. The game still allows you to purchase any weapon from the store and you can get experience for any perk just by killing enemies with weapons from that class.The graphics are great and they really add a beauty to the macabre ugliness of the gore and gruesome monsters. You’ll be exploding heads with every head shot and throwing the game into slow motion for improved accuracy. The maps have a lot of lighting effects, dreary lights, blue hues in rainstorms and a whole series of cheerful lights turned haunting by a creepy atmosphere.The maps offer a vast variety of horrific playgrounds. Dark, sleek nightmarish landscapes. The game started with five maps, but it continues to grow. Abandon shools, hell, a creepy amusement park, ice caves, moon bases, even santa’s workshop was brought out for Christmas. New enemy skins have been produced in the game’s long existence. Its a real testament to how the developer has supported Killing Floor for this long.The maps are free, because they need you to come back in order to purchase optional downloadable content. Everything from weapon packs and character skins. While it is a way to keep the game going to produce new content and keep you engaged, a lot of people might see it as a cash grab. Since you’re all fighting cooperatively against monsters, no one will ever be better than you, but they will just look different than you.With that being said, there are a lot of free mods that you can download from the Steam Workshop to make your game look different and offer interesting ways to change the game. So for everything that you can purchase, there are still free things made by fans. Usually content taken from other games and franchises such as Doom 3’s monsters and Xenomorphs from the Aliens cinemas.In terms of character customization, there are several character skins to chose from. They do nothing other than change the look of your character to other players. There are no mirrors to admire yourself in game when you’re grenading monsters to death.Killing Floor is still a fun game and its been dirt cheap in the past. It still has a booming community, but there are other games that offer horde mode and so much more.

content:
ry 13, 2011
												Really awesome, I'd say better than CoD Zombies.Alrighty, time to update this review:I've been playing this game for the majority of almost 3 years now, and I still enjoy playing it. For beginners, it has a lot of replayability value (since obtaining level six perks takes quite a while) which can take from 100-200 hours. After that, due to the Steam Workshop, there are a lot of options of playing with modded content. There are also dedicated custom servers with custom skins, perks, levels, weapons and more! (I recommend International Gaming Community btw ;) ) The gameplay isn't something to write home about, but there is something about that hooks you on. It's not as team intensive as L4D2, (as in, when there's only one person left, they're basically dead) but it does get close to that point. It's harder to understand the mechanics than L4D2 (since different weapons at different levels for different perks do different thigs to different enemies on different difficulties at different.. see what I'm getting at here?) BUT, once you get the hang of it, the game is tons of fun to play! Get a friend or two, (or three, or four, or five!) and get into a server and go spend hours and hours leveling up! :DIn conclusion, want to shoot zombies with your friends while having a level up game mechanic with different kinds of enemies and perks? Go buy this game! You won't regret it ESPECIALLY since it goes on sale all the time for as low as 5 dollars!

content:
, 2016
												Incredible zombie Coop-Survival. Offering a great variety of maps, weapons and (gruesome) enemies, Killing Floor truthfully enriches the genre. The best and most funny way to play this game is with 5 friends - teamplay is a MUST. Otherwise you won't survive, especially not on the higher difficulty levels.There are 7 different classes in Killing Floor:- Field medic (explains itself)- Support specialist (can wield doors, is best with shotguns)- Sharpshooter (deals extra headshot damage with pistols/rifles)- Commando (is best with assault rifles, can see enemies' health)- Berserker (slashes specimen with melee weapons)- Firebug (excellent BBQ-skills)- Demolition (is best with all kind of explosives)With each class you can get up to level 6. Each level grants more bonuses like discount on weapons for every round, higher precision, and more.The enemies are really strange (in a good way!), and there are a lot of different ones.There is a lot of DLC for this game, luckily you do not need it - the DLC is only for cosmetical reasons.WARNING to players from Germany: The game is censored here (of course). I only recommend this game uncut; Playing a zombie shooter without gore totally destroyes the atmosphere.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2011
												I had done a short/quick review on this a while back, but now with the introduction of the steam reviews system, I figured I might as well take the time and do a proper review for this game.  Killing Floor is by far my most played steam game, and was the entire reasoning for me getting a steam account in the first place.  A friend sent me the "guest pass" for Killing Floor and had me try it out, and then ended up gifting me it for $5 when I enjoyed it.  I first got Killing Floor in August of 2009, so 4 years later and I still play this game daily pretty much.  The replay value is through the roof, not to mention if you buy it on one of the frequent sales (I've seen Killing Floor more than 50% off at least TEN times in the year 2013 so far) will put it under $10 USD.  DLCs might have become a little pricey over the past few years, but the fact that Tripwire Interactive still does free content updates for this game nearly FIVE YEARS post release is simple mind blowing.  I don't know of any other company that continues support for it's product that long into the future.  The few companies that continually support releases that I can think of have all produced sequels to those games.Now to get down to gameplay.  Killing Floor first and foremost is a FPS game.  There are a variety of different types of guns, spread around in 7 different perks or classes.  These perks have a "progression system" that allows a player to get more "profficient" with the weapons of their classes and earn more "bonuses" such as being able to carry more ammo, do more damage, and other things of that nature.  Each perk has a different role which helps a team in it's own unique way.  Like making things blow up, then Demolitions is the perk for you with it's LAW, M32 multiple grenade launcher, m79, and others..  Like setting things on fire and feeding the inner pyromaniac in yourself?  Then firebug is the perk for you with it's flamethrower, flare revolvers, Husk fireball launcher, and other guns with incendiary ammo.  Enjoy the satisfying feeling of blowing an enemies head off?  Then pick the sharpshooter perk, with it's assortment of pistols, sniper rifle, compound crossbow, or various rifles.  Killing Floor has the most satisfying gun play of any game I've ever played.  Excellent feel to the weapons, and they look and sound great.  When it comes to enemies, there are 10 different types of enemies to deal with.  Each one of the "zeds" are similar in some ways, but different in most.  There are the basic enemies, such as the clot, which can grab any perk aside from the beserkser.  Clots don't do all that much damage, but they can make you not able to move and allow the other, more dangerous enemies to get to you and do more damage.  Then you get to the more specialised enemies such as stalkers, which can go invisible, bloats, which puke "bile" on you which can hurt you and ruin your body armor, to sirens, whose screams can shatter glass, destroy rockets, grenades and explosives, break down the welds of doors, and eventually make your head explode, to the husk, resistant to fire attacks (for the most part) who can melee you when up close but is much more dangerous at distance where they can shoot fireballs at you. The more advanced of the enemies are the Scrake, which is a high health enemy with a chainsaw that if it gets close to you, it will start to saw away at your health.  If you are getting attacked by a scrake, don't run, because their full swings and charging attacks do exponentially more damage to you.  Scrakes are best left to sharpshooters which can stun it, berserkers which can do the same thing, or support specialists that know advanced "Techniques" to deal iwth them,Next you have the Fleshpound, which is a big, hulking enemy with high health and hard to kill.  High head damage resistance make it so it shrugs off weaker weapons.  Sharpshooters with good aim and fast reflexes can take them out in a number of ways, but can really only do so one at a time.  Support specialists get explosives bonuses, which make it a good choice to take out fleshpounds (unless there is a siren nearby).  Demolotions is the most polished perk to take down Fleshpounds, as they have a weakness to explosives.  After you finish the "waves" of enemies, you then have to prepare to fight the boss of Killing Floor, the Patriarch.  The patriarch has some vicious melee attacks, and also has an arm with a rocketlauncher/chain gun combination that can and will kill you quick. Defeating the patrairch requires good teamwork and communication generally.Lastly, but not least, is the fact that Killing Floor comes with a free to download SDK system that allows for modding of the game and creation of custom content.  This also comes with a community workshop area dedicated solely to Killing Floor.  So check out the steam workshop and try out some of the amazing modded content there is to offer.

content:
r 20, 2016
UPDATE: I nominated this game for the write-in Steam Award as "The Most Overtly British."Dosh! Grab it while you can, lads.Killing Floor is a wave-based co-op survival shooter. You n' yer mates choose from several different classes (called perks) that focus on different weapon types and playstyles. At the beginning of each game, you start out with nothing but a combat knife, a basic pistol, the welder, and the health injector (unless one of your perks is a high enough level and gives you a bonus weapon at the start). You gain dosh (money) by killing the Zeds (zombies, except they're actually just skinless mutant clones). After each round, the trader opens the doors to her store, and the team is able to use their dosh to buy new weapons, stock up on ammo, grenades, ammo, etcetera. I will be honest. Killing Floor is absolutely my favorite co-op game. The gunplay is fantastic, the multiple different perks allow for great teamplay, and the game has a great sense of humor.Strategy is key on the higher difficulties. If you're not careful, squadmates can easily die within seconds, and the whole team can end up getting swarmed. Team composition is absolutely important. If you don't have a demo laying pipe bombs, a commando/sharpshooter running interference with the regular zeds, a medic (or two) for healing, and a support for straight-up DPS, you're not going to be able to beat the boss on hard or higher.Get this game when it and it's DLC is on sale. The DLC isn't necessary (it's pretty much all cosmetics, and while some of the DLC weapons are completely unique, the achievements that require the unique weapons can be accomplished with base weapons as alternatives), but it's all really great.Wayne Rooney's smarter than you!

content:
29, 2015
												Killing Floor is a co-op survival game wherein you are dropped off in an area full of zeds. A complete round is played on a single map divided with multiple waves with the number of zeds growing as you successfully complete one. After each round you are given a chance to go to the trade and stock up your ammo or buy new guns.Controls[+] What's more to say? WASD and mouse is the best controls for any first person shooter game.[+] Hotkeys for additional actions such as dropping money or a gun for the purposes of giving them to your allies.[+] You can set your own set of hotkeys if you're more used to unorthodox controls.Atmosphere[+] The game is dark. You'd see people hanged themselves and some stabbed on various maps.[+] 'End of the world' feel on the environment.[+] There will always be a time in a round wherein you'll panic because of the zeds coming out of nowhere and suddenly near you.[+] What else could make you ♥♥♥♥ your pants than a zombie holding a ♥♥♥♥ing chainsaw, zombie that can turn invisible and heal himself for injuries, a small crawler that's so hard to see in dark areas and would suddenly jump to you? This game have it all.Sounds[+] Soundtrack that will give you chills.[+] Characters actually talks. Most people would get bored from hearing just random noises and background music.Graphics[+] Despite the requirement being so low-end that it could run almost on any kind of laptop/desktop and being so old. The game still has a very good graphics and even on lowest video settings at that.[+] The zeds are well-made. They give an eerie feeling than most creatures from other games that's supposed to be a horror.Gameplay & Balance[+] The game is challenging and not something you could just play-through casually. The game has different set of difficulties from 'Beginner' to 'Hell on Earth' and the length can be set from 'Short' to 'Long'.[+] The number of zeds scales with how many players are playing on that wave.[+] The maps are designed so that there wont be many safe spots and zombies could literally appear in front of you, to your left/right, and even behind you.[+] The Patriarch, the boss that appears after you successfully finish the last wave. It is really challenging and requires more than just rapid tapping your mouse. He could turn invisible to heal himself and hes hard to beat regardless of the distance since he could attack with both melee and range.[-] It becomes repetitive afterwhile. You just kill, kill, and kill. There's a mission mode wherein you are to complete a set of given objectives but even that won't make up for the repetitiveness of the game. However, don't mistake this statement as to the game not having any replay value. The game has HUGE replay value it's just that it gets repetitive to some after awhile. [-] The game's mapping is too simple. Some small structures like the barrels cant be jumped on.Contents[+] Perks! there are six perks to choose from and each have their own level which you need to work on separately. Different perks provides different bonuses and a different role to take on the party.[+] Different kinds of zombies. Each with different strength and weaknesses.[+] Decent amount of guns classified on their corresponding perk. (More guns when you get the DLCs)[+] Huge selection of characters. There are some that would require you to complete achievements or buy a certain game in order to use them. They provide no boost in your stats just merely appearance. (More chars when you get the DLCs)[+] A lot of maps you could play from and it's wide enough to contain big amount of players and zeds. There are also some spots that were designed to give you a strategic advantage over the mindless zeds.[+] You could get more content from the community members since Killing Floor has its own Steam Workshop.DLCsI want to give a thumbs up for the game developers for making a DLC that would actually increase the game content and provides more fun and eye-candy unlike the DLCs nowadays wherein the game wouldn't be fun unless you get them. (*stares at the Sid Meier games*)

												Do i recommend Killing Floor? Hell yeah!Starting out in KF was daunting for me, since i rarely play FPS games and my only previous experience was in Counter strike.To top it off, i found that i didn't have on-screen crosshairs!Needless to say, the first couple hours of playing this game usually resulted in me dying rather quickly to simple enemies like clots and gorefasts. Damn those buggers are fast..As i continued playing the game, i learned about ammo conservation, and how to make shots count.On lower difficulties you don't really need to worry about ammo too much - unless you're demolitions and shoot off a grenade at anything that moves.On harder difficulties though, you really need to make your shots count, since there are more enemies, they take more shots to kill and you get less reward money for killing stuff.I have bought this game as a gift for several friends and had a absolute blast playing it.Grab it on sale or something, its really cheap and there's really no excuse why you can't afford it.One of the best purchases i made on steam.

content:
ry 27, 2014
												Oh, what to say about this game. Its hard to recomend it outright, because its a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. But its one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games that keeps dragging you back into it.Do I recomend it? Yeah, I suppose so. Over 1000 hours I'd better recomend it. Is it for everyone? No, its not. Its kinda of a cult hit. Most people will get it when its on sale, play a few games of it, and then never touch it again. Others will play it for a few hours, and come back in a few months. But everyone that you see playing Killing Floor year round (not during the holiday events) is a true Killing Floor player.So, pros? Well..-Its got a great modding community; the workshop, Tripwire Interactive forums, and many other sites host great mods and maps, which add to the game.-Great players; on the whole, most players are pretty good. There are some aimbotters that get away with it, some rude people, trolls, the usual. But most people tend to be pretty good.-Modded servers; this is what really gives the game value. Modded servers are the main reason that anyone even plays this game anymore. Without them, this game would be retired.-Lots of custom weapons, skins, and specimens; keeps the game interesting.Cons? Yeah, theres a bunch..-First of all, this game is ancient. Its a mod for Unreal Tournament 2004, using the Unreal 2 engine. So there are some major engine bugs. -Crashes; since its an old game and older engine, the game has trouble handling more than 2gb of ram. On modded servers, often the clients will crash because the engine wasn't meant to handle this. Happens on regular servers too.-Server limitations; dedicated servers have some pretty bad limitations on what you can and can't do. There's a general limit to how many files the server can load at one time, if you exceed that, then the server will hang. -The server also hangs if a weapon/mutator gets added that isn't compatible with a certain map or game mode, thus rendering the server unusable until the admin fixes it.-The voice acting is bad. Like, at first, you're going to think its awful voice acting. 1000 hours later, you want to shoot the voice actors for the obnoxious game speech.-The DLC weapons are community weapons, reskinned and sold by TWI. The player skins are nothing to write home about.-Frameloss; the game engine can't adequatly handle the game itself, and even in a regular solo game, your FPS can go from 100 to 5. Online games? Ha, good luck. Try turning off ambient lighting.-Tripwire doesn't actually fix anything. They push out updates every holiday, maybe a new character skin or map, but thats it. They make intentional changes to break mods and just generally do nothing productive. No fixes to the engine, the gameplay, the menu system, nothing.What DOES tripwire do, though? Break things. Break all the things. This past winter event, they broke the workshop, so every time you launched the game, Steam would download your workshop content. Again. And again. And again. I had 75GB of temporary files that kept increasing in size. It took Tripwire a month to push out a fix for it. An ever-growing list of things they broke~The only reason this game is still alive is because of the modding community and the admins of modded servers. They are the ONLY reason this game is still alive, still being played. And even still, there is no point to this game. This is just a wave based survival game, with the same specimens coming at you, the same bad guns, and the same awful voice acting, over and over. Killing Floor is nothing without the mods. Killing Floor would be better without Tripwire Interactive. There needs to be a Killing Floor 2, or a Killing Floor HD Edition, with-AT THE VERY LEAST- a new game engine, maybe something from the same decade the game was made in.

content:
ry 24
												Killing Floor is a cooperative survival shooter that pits you and up to five other players against wave after wave of genetically modified, humanoid "specimens" that have escaped the laboratory and are rapidly overrunning England. Although they are technically not undead, and the game consistently calls them "specimens," these creatures, which travel around in hoards trying to eat people, certainly won't be offended if you mistake them for zombies. These all-but-zombies come in a variety of breeds, you can kill them with a variety of weapons, and that pretty much sums up the game. Killing Floor is satisfying in its simplicity, though the lackluster graphics are a testament to its humble beginnings as an Unreal Tournament 2004 mod. Even as a full game, it forgoes accouterments such as story, characters, and competitive multiplayer mode, yet where zombie-killing fun is concerned, it delivers in spades.Gameplay in Killing Floor is simple. Slaughter a batch of specimens, buy new equipment from the trader, and repeat until you have a boss fight with "The Patriarch," a nasty misanthrope with a rocket launcher, a chain gun, and the ability to go invisible. No verbose exposition, lengthy cutscenes, or half-baked attempts at character and story development are arbitrarily affixed to this pure first-person-shooter experience. From the beginning, you'll love the game's satisfying gunplay. Guns look and feel real thanks to convincing ballistics and iron sights, which make aiming both important and engaging. In addition, "pray and spray" is worthless on higher difficulty levels, and ammo is often sparse, so every shot counts. To survive the intense and often claustrophobic firefights, you must coordinate with your teammates and make good use of the environment, which you can accomplish by welding shut doors to create temporary choke points, forcing the creatures to fight on your terms. Furthermore, you need to try and complete each round near the trader, who moves her shop between waves (unfortunately she won't sell you her personal teleporter) and opens for business for only less than a minute each time.At the start of each map, you must choose one of six perks that enhance your skills in certain areas and work like classes, minus the restrictions. For instance, field medics are faster at healing themselves and their teammates, whereas commandos do more damage with the assault rifle and are better at spotting invisible enemies. Regardless of which one you're playing at the time, you'll gain experience toward leveling up your perks every time you act appropriately in-game. For example, each headshot, with the right guns, counts toward the sharpshooter perk, and you earn experience for the firebug perk by roasting enemies to a crisp. When selecting a perk, you may want to look at your teammates, because although you can play with a squad full of chainsaw-wielding berserkers, a well-rounded team will increase your chance of survival.Using an algorithm that factors in player achievements, such as long-distance kills and headshots, Killing Floor will occasionally send everyone into slow motion, aka ZED time. (The ZED stands for the same thing as the S in Harry S. Truman: nothing.) Although it can be helpful at higher difficulties, the slow motion kicks in all too often during uninspiring moments--such as when you're trying to turn around--and can become an annoyance, particularly on beginner difficulty. Another annoying situation can come up when you're trying to find and kill the final enemy in a wave. Though they generally succeed at navigating the map, creatures can occasionally become caught on something, and nothing is more frustrating than spending several minutes trying to find the last creature only to discover that it's invisible and stuck on a log 150 meters away from the trader.Although Killing Floor technically has both single-player and multiplayer modes, the lack of any computer teammates means that single-player is good only for playing out your Rambo V: Zombie Apocalypse fantasies. Similarly, Cooperative mode is the only gametype (sorry, competitive players), and there are only five maps, which are, to be fair, all large and nonlinear, with plenty of corners to hide in, doors to weld behind you, and settings for heroic last stands. In multiplayer, your survival depends largely on your teammates, and coordinating with them is both fun and highly advantageous. Unfortunately, ample opportunities for griefing are also available. Mischievous, or simply misguided, teammates can weld shut the door to your escape route, forcing you to choose between going out guns blazing and trying to un-weld a door while fiends chew on your innards. Even more infuriating is not being able to visit the trader because some oaf is blocking the doorway, and given that friendly fire doesn't apply, you can't even execute him or her for it.Visually, Killing Floor compares poorly with contemporary shooters, thanks to its five-year-old engine. Perhaps with this in mind, the developers went for a dark and gritty aesthetic, and when the lights are low, you won't notice how stiff the animations can be. Curiously, most of the specimens are nude, leaving you to wonder whether they rebelled against their masters due to a grossly inadequate clothing budget. The specimens come in familiar varieties, none of which look particularly great, including the zombie with the chainsaw; the zombie that goes invisible; the big, fat zombie that vomits acidic bile; and so on. The most interesting specimen is the fleshpound, a monstrosity with two meat grinders for arms and a giant yellow light on his chest that turns red when you provoke him, prompting a frenzied and deadly rampage. As far as gore is concerned, headshots provide delightful fountains of blood, and you can occasionally sever limbs, but the chainsaw feels anticlimactic. What's the point in having a chainsaw if you can't dismember zombies in a geyser of viscera that would fill the Roman Coliseum?The sound effects are outstanding, especially for guns, and you can often use subtle sound clues to detect incoming enemies. Unfortunately, the voice acting and soundtrack don't achieve the same level of quality. To be fair, the problem with the voice acting is mostly with the script, except for the trader, who is just all-around bad. She constantly harasses you with repetitive and unappealing sexual innuendos, and the medics incessantly bleat that they are trying to heal you rather than "shag you." Meanwhile, derivative, generic metal music does little to improve the tone, though it does lend itself well to blasting zombies.Killing Floor is permeated by a sense that you're having way more fun that you ought to be. It's absurd and crass, and yet you can't help but enjoy it. Maybe there is something inherently entertaining about gunning down hordes of zombies. Maybe the simple formula of fight, flight, or weld speaks to some primal part of the human brain. Whatever the reason, Killing Floor will have you gleefully decapitating monsters like the reincarnation of an ancient war god. It's just plain fun, and for only $20 you could do a lot worse.

												As it is know to all ,Killing Floor is a fantastic co-op game ,however ,if you never play it or just watching video of others' playing video ,you won't under the joy of cooperation and the fighting skill which you have to use in this game .   Many remarkable reasons contribute to how hard the game is which lead to some people direct their eyes upon this wonderful game and step back ,yes it is,it very unfriendly to new players.If you play with 0-1 level ,even Easy Mode will get your goat,especially when you play with other 5 players and all of them died left you alone to fight agaist 100+ monster ,even most of them are clot while 5-6 Bloat among them,what make it worse is that the space so small that it suddenly become a very horrific experience.Due to this fact,I give a suggestion to new player:play solo at first to promote your level,because in solo Mode monsters have less health than multiplayer Mode.Beside, the best solo map ,in my opinion ,is KF-farm for the map is the most broader one, workshop has a map whose name is KF-farm-day,which change the time from night to morning and the environment become  lighter so you won't feel very horror.   Judging from the evidence offered, we might safely draw the conclusion that this is a great coop game that you shouldn't miss(patients with 3D vertigo is another matter ):  1:multiple monsters,maps and weapons.You wont get bored with such abundant elements while play with your friends time and again.Each wave you will meet different collocation of monsters,some time in 7 wave you will meet one FleshPound with  several SC,just attack the FP shoulder to shoulder for the first,later for the SCs, a sharpshooter with a crossbow is enough to deal with them,however ,once we met 5 FP,the game became harder within a while,fortunately,we succeed in wipe out all of them finally,or we would be wiped out.If you get bored with the official maps,many fantastic maps in workshop is waiting for you.So there is no wonder that many people play this for over thousand hours.   2,high requirement to cooperation.If anyone dead  after the wave come no long will be bad for the whole team.So cure your teammates timely and shoot the monsters which attack your mates from the back.whatever happen you should stick with your teammates.Guard a point which easy to attack monsters is a good idea but CANT DEFEND TO DEATH,the team should move according to the situation,or the whole team would be wiped out.Above all,as far as I'm consider,though KF2 is released,there would still have many newplayers for KF1,if he/she makes mistakes you should tolerant them for you were also a  noob like them,think about the others' tolerance let you love this game.It's a coop game not a competive game,you play it just for fun,so whatever happen not let you unhappy and others' player unhappy,Of course,I don't mean you can use cheat tool ,if so,VAC is waiting for serving you.WHAT I WANT TO SAY TO EVERY COOP GAME FAN WHO DON'T OWN THIS GAME  IS:If this game on discount,don't hesitate,just BUY IT!

content:
1, 2014
												I never thought I'd get so hooked to a game this suddenly and this quickly. With the different perks, different 'classes' of ZEDs and countless amounts of (custom) maps (in either mindlessly-slay-'em-all or Objective modes) - Killing Floor never really gets boring, and sometimes even though you think, oh I played so much this week, I might not want to anymore ... hahaha, well, YOU'RE WRONG. Leveling up is quite easy in the beginning and later on takes a lot of determination (it takes quite some time to collect all the required kills/headshot/damage points etc) - but it still is fun and gives you even more purpose than just freeing a district, abandoned warehouse, or farming area one ZED at a time. The added advantages you gain with each level up are also great (and another incentive)! The whole thing of earning money to buy your weapons is really cool. It's especially nice to see  when people really play as a team and help each other out when cash is short, or when they pick up an expensive weapon, after you tragically died defending your squad's core existence, to faithfully hand it back into your respawned hands. Of course, playing experience always depends on your co-players, and maybe the difficulty too (Normal is actually quite challenging already), and depending on the moon phase and the godesses' benevolent minds it can be quite a frustrating experience or the most fun you've had in a long, long time - so long ago, it's such a distant memory it doesn't quite come washing to the surface but just tickles your metaphorical gamer-nose with a satisfying, nostalgic odour. Personally I've made some great gaming friends just by excessively indulging in playing Killing Floor. With some I talk and laugh a lot, and I adore them, and others, well ... we might not talk much, but when we're facing the ZEDs side by side, wave after wave, you can just feel the bonding experience hanging thick in the air between us. We do not need to talk. We just wordlessly decapitate together. It's great!I am very much in favour of this game and I am already anxiously looking forward to the successor - hoping that they are going to surprise me delightfully with more female playable characters. Because in Killing Floor there is the Traders, a people of monovular sisters ... clones, even? Who are in ownership of all the weapons available in these godforsaken places. No matter where you go, the ZEDs are there, the Traders are there (coincidence? I think not).In terms of female playable characters, they are two that I am aware of. Two.Two? Really? TWO? (And you have to buy them. You do not even get to play a default female soldier or ANYone like that). Biggest booing!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
16, 2014
												A very simple co-op horde shooter with surprising depth and replayability. The premise is pretty simple; bad stuff happened at a biotech lab somewhere in the UK and you've got to fight them, the story doesn't actually matter except to explain why you're fighting what you're fighting where you're fighting them, though. The vanilla game consists of several waves of a set number of enemies (Zeds), the composition of these waves increases with difficulty as you go along, and the game also scales in difficulty (number of enemies and their health) depending on the number of players and, of course, the difficulty you set. Generally speaking you can finish a Normal round with a disorganised team of randoms, but by the time you get to Hell on Earth you'll need a well-rounded team who know what they're doing, so there's a lot more to the game - in an 'emergent', sort-of-exploity kind of way; things like how hitboxes aren't synced to clients so you can't always get a headshot by aiming for the head or how if you jump and look down while shooting certain enemies at point blank range the bullets can hit more than once, thereby saving you ammo - than you'd ever figure out for yourself.All in all, if you have a group of people to play with, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this. If you don't and you just want to play with randoms, you probably won't ever experience the game at its hardest. The community, like many others, is a mixture of people who will accept new players and try to teach them and others who will kick low level players on sight. Which, honestly, is kind of justified; low level players physically cannot keep up with anything harder than Normal difficulty.

content:
15
												This game is by far the best first person shooter i have ever played. I own alot of games such as far cry,tomb raider,saints row and many others and yet I'm still attracted to this game. Sure this is a normal FPS game which is very common but this game is very different in it's aspects,gameplay,team cooperation and mechanicsFirst thing out,this is a team HORROR game and trust me it's a very good horror at that. I usually get scared by the spawns of the ZEDs as they spawn infront of me or worse,I walk into the middle of the group spawns. Sure it's annoying but that will teach me a lesson for wandering about. The ZEDs themselves have an amazing and terrifying design,from the small and puny clots to the godly fleshpounds. The design of the maps is very dark and gloomy which adds to the ambiance and scenic of the game. It gives that extra spooky effect. And if it is too dark for you,turn up the brightness. But beware if your playing on low brightness hehehe, that glowing yellow object? Stay away from it.Second things is by m far my favourite and that is teamwork. Wait you don't know what team work is? Well stopping running around the map quuick-scoping people. But seriously this game really recommends teamwork to aid in your survival. This however still depends on your team mates. Bad and selfish team? Instant death. Good and caring team? Instant win. I should also touch up on the perk system. There are seven main perks which are Field Medic-Focuses on healing team mates and keep them alive as well as your self. Your the most tankiest class so its good if you take the damage for your team.Support specialist-Focuses on taking out the big guys mainly.Sharpshooter- Clears thrash (Small ZEDs) and big guys too.Firebug-Not the best class, it is good for thrash clearing but if you love fire,then this is one for you.Demolitionist-BOOM BOOM BOOM!!!! Who wouldn't love this class? Explosive and focuses on killing big guys as well as BLOWING EVERY SINGLE LAST ZED TO PIECES!!!!!Berzerker- The melee guys for those who like it up close and personal( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) Your sword is your friend, guns? Ew who wants that. You will love running around the map and kill the ZEDs and most fun is when you tackle on the big guys.Commando-another meh perk but i wouldn't say it is that bad. Their main focus is clearing thrash and being A ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AND STEALING MY ♥♥♥♥ING SCRAKE AND FLESHPOUND KILLS!!!!!! But if you love rifles then knock yourself out with this one.These perk have a max level of 6, wait 6? That's it? Don't worry pal,the way to level up is so hard you rather play the game then focus on leveling up. I have 200 hours on this game and i only have 3 level 6. That's alot to learn from that statement.Lastly,ay ay don't sleep on me yet man. This is the last point. The last thing you can do on this game is solo and earn achivements. WAIT,WAIT!! DON'T COME NEAR ME. I KNOW I SAID TEAMWORK IS IMPORTANT HEAR ME OUT FIRST! Solo is very fun and very scary. The reason being is because YOUR THE ONLY ONE ALIVE. And if you die well,game over man you gotta start a new map and from scratch again. But hey thats the fun part. Dying over and over again is annoying from my experience but that is the best part. You'll die and think maybe if i had done that i would have survived. Or maybe if i done that i would still die but killed most of the ZEDs. So when you die you'll think of what you could or could not have done to survive. And there are tons of achivements so you won't feel bored and you will have something to do. Uh one more thing hehe. SHUT THE ♥♥♥♥ UP I'M ALMOST DONE! The one bad thing about this game is the servers. THERE ARE TONS OF THEM. But good luck finding the one in your region hahaha.Also one more thing to point is the DLC. Yes i know they are very expensive but don't worry. There are mostly gun and weapon DLC and won't affect the gameplay at all. I only own the neon character pack and no weapon DLC and the game still feels the same. (I'm getting more DLC in the future so stfu)So in conclusion killing floor is indeed a very good game. And horror game. I highly recommend the game to those who are considering to get it. The graphics may not look good but trust me the gameplay is fantastic. The community is honestly dying and i don't want this to be a dead game. Most of the members are moving on to killing floor 2 because it is more "MODERN". So I'm saying this again, this is a wonderfull 2009 game and you will love it if you out your heart to it.Thanks for reading and i hope you enjoy killing floor the same way i do.

content:
2, 2014
												Killing Floor is a wave based, co-op, zombie survival game. Its addictive perk leveling system will keep me playing for days and days. This game is often compared to the Left For Dead series and while it is similar, the gameplay is very different. L4D is going from point A to B while KF is to try to survive each wave until you meet the boss. You have 7 perks/classes to choose from. Each perk has a role to play during the game and it's here that teamwork is needed to survive as the higher you go in difficulty the harder the game becomes for the entire team. You have a number of weapons to choose from depending on your chosen perk too. The game is quite easy to learn, survive each wave of specimens and go to the trader to buy weapons, armour, etc.  You'll then face the end of game boss, the Patriarch and he will take some skill to take down. He is heavily armed, and also very fast. Furthermore he can cloack making him even more of a threat as you'l often find him appearing in the middle of the team without any warning. The maps are very big and well designed too. A great team based game and i highly recommend it!

content:
er 29, 2013
Killing Floor is a fantastic family game, which combines aspects of team building, puzzle solving, and perception. It will surely give you hours, or maybe even days of fun. When you start the game, you have the option to play by yourself or cooperative. Since this is a family game, playing solo is not recommended as it will not give you the full experience of Killing Floor. The co-op games can have up to 6 players, that means you, your brother or sister, your parents, maybe your favorite grandparents and your pet warthog. The goal is simple: Have as much fun as possible! You and your teammates will be put in classic maps like kf_abusementpark and kf_hellride. Before you can play, you will have to select a so called ''perk''. It is recommended that all players play field medic, because their special funbombs have a lovely green glow when thrown, but I'll come to that later. After everyone clicked on 'ready up' you will spawn in the chosen map. Take a moment to look around in these beautiful places, because there are many things to be seen. I myself have found a sleeping horse, a dancing robot, a man with a television head, and a mini caravan. Soon you will realize that you are in fact, holding a gun. This is a glitch that should be fixed by the developers, because people might get a wrong idea from what this game is about. It is recommended that you press "5" to switch to your love dispenser. Soon you will hear the joyful cheers of the npcs in this game. There is the Clot, a little elf that will hug you *with force*, the delicious Gingerbreadman, the beautifully constructed snowman called ''Husk'', the Siren (who will sing for you) , Rudolph the crawling reindeer, the Scrake (I think he's made out of ice cream :3), the Bloat (Santa Claus), the Patriarch (Bigger Santa) When these npcs hug your or give you colorful flying thingies, your screen will get red from ketchup, it is really fun! Oh and.. ahem.. the Stalker.  I'd like the developers to delete this npc, as it is inappropriately clothed. It does NOT belong in a family game like Killing Floor. I hope it is just a bug like the guns and other weapons in this game. Overall this game is fun, and you (or a family member) should defenitly get it, but the developers should really fix the various bugs in this game. pi/5 would play again.

												Aside from all the le money simulator maymay jokes this game is actually great.The money is required to upgrade weapons(like all games) but like zombie defense games should be you earn money from every ZED you kill. Depending on the difficulty you are playing you also recieve a a set amount of cash at the end of each wave. content:
17, 2011
												Killing Floor is a co-op game, where you can play alone, about experiments gone wrong and invading London (and the world too as seen in KF2 and as seen on some KF maps). Your goal is to survive 4,7 or 10 waves of enemies, while earning money by killing them (or by healing your teammates) so that you can buy powerful weapons during the minute of calm at the trader between the waves. After, you'll have to defeat the Patriarch, who is the sole responsible for the chaos. You can choose different difficulties: Easy (which is really to learn the game), Normal, Hard, Suicidal and Hell on Earth.Enemies are thougher depending on the difficulty but you too can evolve and acquire advantages like spawning with a better weapon than a pistol or armor thanks to the level system. You have 6 of them and it takes time. However, you have different classes: medic (no powerful weapon but more resistance  and better health), commando (rifles and can see stalkers from apart), support (big guns and better welder), demo (everything that is explosive), berserker (melee and also can't be grabbed), sharpshooter (sniper and headshots more efficient) and firebug (flame everywhere).Enemies are varied: from the simple Zed to the infamous Fleshpound that can kill you quickly, without forgetting the Scrake and the chainsaw, the Gorefast that cuts you in pieces, the Crawler that loves your feet, the Stalker who is hidden, the Husk that launches fireballs, the Siren that is hurting your ears (and your health)....Anyway, the game in its actual state contains many maps (some are official, others done by modders) and mutators with Christmas-themed or Halloween-Themed or Circus-Themed enemies (because they were parts of special events). The maps are very varied: fair, tunnel of love, Santa's workshop or cave, asylum, Horzine labs, urban town, mountain, hospital, etc..But you'll ask me: what about the DLC? Well, all the DLC are cosmetic. True, you have new weapons in them and they can be used for achievements. However, you can do them with the standard weapons, that are enough like the AA12 for example. And you can unlock avatars by playing with themed mutators for example or owning other games. And that's how you own two Mr Foster (the normal and the steampunk).Killing Floor in solo holds interest if you want to level without having a team to check or to win map achievements in Normal/Hard. An higher difficulty is better with a team, however, keep in mind that some of the players aren't using the perks for the team but for themselves. I've seen many medics choosing this perk for the advantages it's giving in terms of resistance or health but not healing at all the team for example. It's annoying as hell and if I seems to be upset by this kind of behavior, it's because I'm a medic first in this game, because I feel more useful by healing my teammates than beginning to put pipe bombs, welding the right doors or being a specialist of the crossbow. Healing is important in that game and if a medic is there, he's more powerful for the heal than the rest of the team. Not using of that fact can result in premature death on high difficulty.Anyway, with Killing Floor 2, I don't know if there are still a lot of players there. I still need to win Suicidal and Hell on Earth achievements, as I've all Hard and Normal and that all my perks are lvl5+. But it's still worthy to play. As long as there are servers and as long as the solo mode is there, Killing Floor is really a very strong co-op game. However, make sure that you're not discouraged when level 0. By patience, by learning and by leveling, you'll find more and more pleasure to survive these waves.

er 10, 2013
												One of the better zombie shooters out there! Loads of maps, modded maps and achievements will keep you busy for hours. Solid MP gameplay for up to 6 players (official maps). Teamwork is key especially in the stages of Suicidal and Hell on Earth. Aside from the regular maps there is also an objective mode where you have to complete certain missions. The seasonal events keep the game alive and will guarantee new DLC and new achievements over time. Buy it!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 5, 2015
												If you like wave-based FPS games where you can purchase better weaponry between rounds, Killing Floor most likely has your name on it. Besides having a solid arsenal, there are some fearsome and gruesome enemies to be fought. Killing Floor takes place in England. Some scientists were toying with human tissue and ended up by mistake making zombie specimens. There are two types of modes in Killing floor : Killing Floor and Objective. Killing Floor mode is a horde defense type game. After every successful round, the player is allowed to upgrade buy more ammo for their arsenal. Every kill will equal more money for disposable income. Every new level becomes more difficult until the final boss appears. In objective mode, there are specific challenges that players need to pass against certain zombies. To win a round, at least one player needs to remain alive to win. There are a lot of categories of weapons (or perks) to choose from as well as specific weapons. The categories are melee, pistols, support, commando, sharpshooter, firebug, demolition, field medic, berserker, perk neutral, and non-damaging. Melee weapons range from knives (almost spelt knifs), machetes, fire axes, katanas, chainsaws, claymores, sytches and a dwarves axe. Pistols range from regular 9mm to dual handcannons. Support comes in the form of shotguns, impalers, a "zed" thrower and a AA12. Commando weapons include bullpup, AK-47, M4 carbine, tommy gun, MKb and SCAR's. Sharpshooter weapons include lever-action rifle, single piston long musket, compound crossbow, M14 EBR and M99 AMR. Firebug guns include Mac-10, trenchgun, flare revolver and flamethrower. Demolition weapons include L.A.W, grenade launcher, seeker six, M4 203 with grenade attachment, Harpoon Bomber, m79 grenade launcher, orca bomb propeller, pipe bomb and grenade. Field medic weapons include Mp7, Mp5, M7A, Schneidzekk and the blower thrower bile launcher. There is a single berserker weapon which includes a buzzsaw bolt. Neutral perks include a zed eradication device as well as a MKII version and finally, non damaging weapons include medical syringes and a welder. You're probably wondering what the heck is a welder doing in the game? The welder can sort of "lock" or weld doors shut in the game. The AI is smart though and will take a different route in a certain door is locked. To un-weld a door, simply press alt+fire. Each perk is selected at the beginning of the round and can level up. Graphically, the engine is nice and the dismemberment of the hordes is awesome. Sounds are pretty decent and provide for a nice ambience. Some of the screams that come from the infected specimens is quite chilling. Overall, a pretty good game if you're hardcore into FPS, zombie and horde type genre. I have quite a few friends that do not like the game due to it's type but the mods can keep you coming back for more. RATING :  7.0/10Gameplay B- Story / Campaign N/A Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B- Overall  B-

												This is a fun co-op wave based zombie killing games. It has a lot of good maps, and you can download many user created maps too. Theres 5 difficulties, and theres always people playing on each one. Hacking is not a problem in this game. I've never seen a hacker. Most often its teams of 6 people going through 10 waves of zombies, but there are shorter games and some with more players. Theres is also an objective mode. If you plan on getting every achievement prepare to spend hundreds of hours in this. The things that make you want to keep playing are leveling up each class, and getting achievements. Each class goes up to level 6 and it takes a while to get there. I think this games a lot of fun. I'd definitely recommend it, especially for the sale price.

19, 2014
												This is not your standard wave after wave zombie survival game with slow mindless beings coming after you. Nine types of ZED’s (name for these zombies, that aren’t actually zombies at all) with their own special traits, Seven classes to choose from with their own perk from damage reduction, faster reloads or bigger magazine sizes with their style of weapon or a free starting gun if you level up enough. All thrown on maps from open Mountain passes to tight corridors in the Bio labs that they come from means you got your work cut out, so grab some friend (the ones that can aim) and get stuck in. Ow, and once you think you have survived the waves there’s one last little surprise for you, seem like the Patriarch doesn’t like you killing his children, See you on the battlefield, if you survive.

content:
er 10, 2014
												Did you know? Killing Floor was originally a mod for Unreal Tournament 2004. Did you also know it was made by the same team who made Red Orchestra, another UT2004 Mod?Tripwire Interactive's track record is pretty good when it comes to mods to games and Killing Floor is extremely good. You are part of a small 6 man team of varying perks to try and overcome the Zed Horde, from the simple Clot, the loud and proud Siren, the scary Fleshpound and the big bad Patriarch.  Fighting through waves, you must survive by getting mad amounts of dosh and buying bigger and badder weapons from the Trader.Gameplay is pretty good when solo or with a group of friends, it can get frantic at times, but it's still a fun ride along the way. And if you get tired of the base game, Killing Floor can be customized like it's parent, UT2004. Though with the Workshop function, it's a whole lot easier to install mods (I recommend subscribing to the Weapons Workshop Mod for having custom weapons to work).Map are generally ranged from close quarters to rare big and large maps, and the visuals are pretty decent.My major gripe is with the music, a lot of it's heavy metal stuff, but over time the music just becomes grating and uninteresting. There's stuff in the Workshop to change the music, but MP3 support would be nice.And after a while Killing Floor does become wholely reptitve, even the objective mode gets tedious because there's not a lot of maps for it. But it's still a good dame throughout and I whole-heartedly reccommend it for those who like zombie games.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												Experimentin' stuff has gone bad. Crazy experiments are on the loose. Whole cities are abandoned (or all inhabitants are exterminated, but hey, no one had time to inform you about that!). No one knows where you are, but as a cold comfort: most people don't even care whether or not you survive, so even if they could, they wouldn't help you. You and your squad are on your own, surrounded by experiments and weird humanoid-looking-ish fusions that are basically your worst nightmare, and theyre out there to eat you. Exterminate them all or they will have you grilled medium rare for dinner.AND AS IF THAT WASN'T BAD ENOUGH YET, once you destroyed enough experiments, the creator and 'father' of them will appear, and he wont be happy! But who could blame him? You'd be mad too if a random squad of 6 weirdos would come and kill hundreds and hundreds of your children!This is the premise of Killing Floor, a first person shooter that brings you to a (maybe not so original, but who cares, as long as you can shoot things) scenario in which you're the last men standing against monstrous opponents. With a good variety of enemies and five difficulty levels, this game is gamer-friendly for the newbiest of newbies and challenging for the experienced exterminator, whereas every different enemy will require a different strategy to get rid of when you play on the highest difficulty level. You will level up your classes on the go to match your characters abilities with the level you'll be playing on. With the 7 different playable classes (or Perks) you can play your preferred role in a team, so you'll have your favourite way of destroying evil: Fightin' (or kitin') like a MAN? play Berzerker. Steady aim, ready to take out the big threats? play Sharpshooter. Do you like to watch the world burn? play Firebug. Like gibs flyin' around and explosions? play Demolitions. Assault rifles 'n kalashnikovs 'n stuff? play Commando. Wanna be that guy that carries a million different (and heavy) guns? play Supports specialist. Do you love ze healing, not ze hurting? play Field medic!This all comes with a sh*tload of different maps in completely different settings (woods, buildings, cities, north pole, on a ship, on the moon, EVERYWHERE), able to keep your interest for quite a while. Also contains objective modes to keep the diversity in the game.STILL haven't had enough? There's an incredible amount of custom content with EVEN MORE perks to level up to even greater heights, additional objective modes with a wide range of different goals to achieve.To top this off, your squad consists of whiny, cocky british people with a strong accent, so insults, directions and calls for help will sound hilarious! Despite many negative remarks on the 'crappy' voice acting, I actually think the lack of seriousness these squad members show with their snarky voice commands adds nicely to the game's attractiveness.Pros:- A million different guns- Dont like guns? It has explosives too- AND fire- AND melee weapons- Playable at all skill levels- A lot of variety in the maps- Challenging and interesting action on higher levels (especially as berzerker in my opinion)- Enemies with chainsaws- A boss with a machine gun for an arm- ^I forgot to mention his OTHER arm is a FRIGGIN' ROCKET LAUNCHER- Has nice skin overrides with christmas, halloween and in the summer.- "Help me or I'll be pushin' up the bloody daisies!"Cons- By far not the best graphics (Don't get me wrong, they're not terrible!)- Camping to survive waves on high difficulty can get stale easily (but there's kiting to make up for that)- Not the most serious and realistic shooter (I personally don't mind, but I know many will see this as a downside)"YOU MURDERED MY CHILDREN": prepare to fight, stock up on the biggest, baddest guns and bombs and sht and take the challenge! A great gore-spattered shooter that will be guaranteed entertainment for a long time!Rating: 9/10

content:
, 2014
												Pros:Good gameplay loop.Amazing weapons.Cons:Repetitive, bound to lose your interest eventually.Holy hell does this game have one hell of a grind. Not only will it take hundreds of hours to unlock everything, but the grind holds you back from playing on higher difficulties. Unlike other games where a grind will usually just unlock new gear that is at least arguably a sidegrade, you get a bonus to every stat for each perk (class) that gives higher level players a direct advantage over lower level players. There's no good reason for it either. Lower level players can still play on higher difficulties, so it doesn't prevent new players from joining harder difficulties than they should, it only makes it even harder to win when they do join. The levelling might be fine if it was shorter, but for each individual perk it takes probably a little less than 50 hours to grind out on average. (Things like sharpshooter and medic level up relatively quickly, things like Commando or Support take absolutely forever and frankly skew that average to higher than it probably would be otherwise.)Conclusion:I would still recommend it in the end, but keep in mind that it's probably going to eventually become something you lose interest in with the repetitiveness. Just keep in mind that while it is a gem, it is greatly flawed gem.

content:
er 29, 2013
												I got this game during the Halloween Sale after being interesting in it after watching Roosterteeth do a 'Lets Play' of it, and I must say that is a very fun game to play either by yourself or with friends as a team.This is a wave based game pitting you and/or a team against 10 waves of ever increasingly diffcult monsters, each with thier own unique way of making surviving difficult for you. After beating the 10th wave you and your team are pitted against the 'Patriarch' who will test you and your teams skill and ability to work together to the max.+ Fun and simply gameplay to learn.+ Huge arsenal of weapons to destroy your enemies.+ Very creative set of maps with the game constantly including new maps created and recommended by the community.+ Funnest game to play with your friends.- Can be cruel if you die during a wave as you lose your weapon and some ingame money.- Whole team dying except one on wave 10 can make respawning and then fighting wave 11 almost impossible.Overall this is very fun game to play, with developers who respect the community by importing custom made maps in, and also custom made weapons offcially imported, also more awaits in the Steam Workshop.Overall Score: 7/10

content:
er 23, 2013
												Killing Floor is an incredible co-operative survival shooter. You can play solo, or join up with up to 5 other players to face waves of specimen trying to kill you. The specimen are enemies with big variety. Some are weak but can be tough in groups. Some are tough and can kill your whole squad single-handedly if you're poorly prepared.After each wave the game will progressively become harder, and tougher specimen will spawn. Between each wave the trader will open up her shop and you will be able to purchase a variety of weapons. You all have a perk that gives you bonuses and makes you more effective with certain weapons and levels up as you play. For example Support specialist are good with shotguns, commandos with assault rifles, berserkers with melee weapons and so on. After all rounds are complete you will face the final boss, the patriarch, and your teamwork will be put to the test.The game can get rather difficult. One big part about this game is the progression and the long learning curve. You won't be able to beat every map on the first try. You will learn about the enemies, the maps, the perks and the weapons as you play. And after mastering a difficulty you can move on to a higher difficulty and the rules will change. You will need new spots to defend at, new weapons to use and new tactics. This might be a drawback to some, but to somebody who likes long learning curves, it's perfect.The graphics are very good but not the latest. The game is from 2009 but still has impressive graphics. It's well optimized and can run well on decent hardware. The maps varies in quality but some are very well made and makes for a very good atmosphere. The game has quite some gore. It is well made and can be enjoyed during the Zed time. Zed time is when the whole server goes slow motion for a few seconds. Watching a Fleshpund blow to pieces right before you just as he about to shred you to pieces in slow motion is nothing short of awesome.The audio is also very good. The sound effects and the music are well made. The music changes from map to map and really adds to the atmosphere. It's fast-paced during the waves and makes shooting specimen a lot more fun.Killing Floor also has season events, three times a year. Every summer, halloween and winter all skins of the specimen change  during the event. New maps, weapons and achievements are also introduced. It keeps the game constantly fresh and always fun to come back to.Killing Floor is a really great game. It has improved a lot since it was released and still does wth constant updates. I highly recommend it.

content:
, 2016
												This game is pure fun! I'll tell you why :1. No need to worry about the numbers of people playing the game : you'll always find a lot of servers, even though this game is 7 (!!!) years old!2. Zombies (zeds as they call 'em) everywhere!3. Slow-mo so you can see all the details when blowing someone's brains off.4. Polished co-op so you're going to need some communication and strategy in order to beat the game.5. Great dificulity scale! You can play a short casual round just for fun, or if you want a challenge you can try an long expert playtrough which will surely put you under pressure!6. Many maps, weapons, a lot of customization ( Workshop is also included )7. Different game modes , including sandbox and a mutation bar if you wanna take it to another level...8. Bloody as hell xDCONCLUSION : Buy this as fast as u can! I'm 100% sure u won't regret it ;)

r 7, 2016
												great game. i think i got it for free when buying red orchestra 2 (which is also great) or as a gift when buying kf 2 (which i havent played much yet, because it was beta then and i wanted to complete kf 1 first). so i started playing it in 2015 when it already was old. what i like about it, is the great balance in classes and enemys. at first i thought the wave breaks are also immersion breaks, and they somewhat are, but they bring in a tactical element, which can be crucial in higher difficulties, that is nice. its pleasing that you can hunt down so many achievements, i really like to do that. and that its a growing challenge to beat the higher difficulties, but still in a fair manor. personally i enjoy the solo mode for this game, havent played multiplayer too much and whitnessed quite a lot of lag there, but that might not be representing. the maps are also pretty creative and community works are implemented heavily. you get so much content and playtime in a well thought out game. it still does not feel old today, in fact it feels better than many modern products. respect & love for that.

Ok, that's a bit too easy.Killing Floor is a charming zombie (or "zed") survival shooter game in wich you and a couple of other individuals weld doors, insult monsters, die because they CAN'T TAKE IT LIKE A MAN, toss around money and in some cases PANIC PANIC PANIC.
